results.title: The Ingrate
results.creator_credit: American Mutoscope and Biograph Company and D.W. Griffith
results.brief_description: A young bank clerk’s love for the daughter of the bank’s president proves to be a dilemma which eventually turns into a disaster for one and all. Cast includes Herbert Yost, Florence Lawrence, Arthur V. Johnson.

results.title: The Ingot
results.creator_credit: Frank A. Hoare, Merton Park, Film Producers Guild and John Durst
results.brief_description: More than 97% of the steel produced in Britain is cast into ingots. The different methods of teeming molten steel into ingot moulds are shown in this film, which also illustrates with sectional diagrams the difference between the main types of ingot and explains the purpose for which each type is generally used.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank A. Hoare, Merton Park, Film Producers Guild and John Durst

results.title: The Informative label
results.brief_description: An explanation of how manufacturers test their products and assign ‘facts labels’ giving points to various qualities eg. durability, colour fastness. This enables consumers to compare directly the wares of different manufacturers.

results.title: The Information machine: or creative man and the data...
results.creator_credit: IBM, Charles Eames and Ray Eames
results.brief_description: Made for the IBM pavilion at the Brussels World’s Fair, it attempts to clearly place the electronic computer in the context of human development, suggesting that it is a logical extension of our desire to connect and relate things. Explains the nature of data processing, beginning with primitive man and ending with the advent of machine simulation. Drawings and animation by Dolores Cannata, music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: The Infinite Variety
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life on Earth”.
David Attenborough examines the beginnings of life on earth. It took nearly 3,000 million years for life to evolve from the first primitive cells to a single creature such as a jellyfish, and these stages of evolution are traced.

results.title: The Industrious flame
results.creator_credit: Frank Green, Ace Films, British Gas Council and John Miller
results.brief_description: Demonstrates that heat is essential in practically all industries to process raw materials. States that gas is one of the most economical sources of heat and shows its use in the pottery, steel sheet, baking and electric globes industries.

results.title: The Industrial revolution
results.brief_description: Primitive humans employed animals to supplement their own strength and labour power, and this method of production has been common to all civilizations. Technological development which went hand in hand with the increase in the complexity of European civilization, particularly the development of machines, gradually replaced the labour-power of men and draught animals in many aspects of production. The social and economic implications of industrialisation are noted.

results.title: The Industrial revolution
results.creator_credit: Hugh Baddeley Productions and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: The story of the industrial developments that transformed the cottage industries of the eighteenth century into the power-driven factories of the nineteenth century. Describes development of the steam-engine, inventions in the textile industry and developments in communications and transport.

results.title: The Individual in the modern world
results.brief_description: The Corning Foundation and the American Council of Learned Societies in 1961 co-sponsored a second Corning conference on the theme “The Individual and the modern world”. Distinguished Americans and other world figures held informal sessions on work, education and leisure. These far ranging discussions became the subject for this film.

results.title: The Individual
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Army
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Hospital food service personnel training”.
Instructions in methods of preventing communicable diseases associated with improper food handling. Illustrates habits that should be avoided by cooks and waitresses including dirty clothes and hands, untidy hair, and handling of the eating surface of crockery and cutlery.
